elements.title: Monthly Income-First Pricing Hierarchy
elements.problem: The current pricing information architecture leads with per-night rates, which anchors professional hosts on the smallest economic unit. Tammy's decision tree starts with 'Does this meet my monthly minimum?' — not 'What is the nightly rate?' Kahneman's anchoring research shows that the first number presented becomes the reference point. When per-night rate is the primary information, it anchors on $85, which primes 'small amount' and 'uncertainty.' The host must then perform mental multiplication ($85 x nights x weeks x tenants) to reach the number that actually matters to them. This cognitive burden is placed on the host at the exact moment when System 1 is deciding whether to engage. The information hierarchy is inverted relative to the host's decision hierarchy.
elements.solution: Restructure the pricing information hierarchy to match the professional host's decision tree: (1) PRIMARY: Estimated monthly income (aggregate across all paired tenants for this unit), displayed as a single prominent number. (2) SECONDARY: How this compares to the host's stated monthly minimum or market rate, shown as a visual comparison (bar, percentage, or delta). (3) TERTIARY: Breakdown by tenant (Mon-Thu guest at $85/night, Fri-Sun guest at $100/night), available on expansion but not primary. (4) QUARTERNARY: Per-night rate details, seasonal adjustments, and occupancy assumptions — available in a detail view. The hierarchy inverts from bottom-up (nightly → weekly → monthly) to top-down (monthly → breakdown → nightly), matching the host's decision flow.

evidence.quote: I can look to people all day long at 5,000 a month for the two bedroom, one bath.
evidence.insight: Her unit of economic thinking is monthly. All pricing information must be denominated in this unit first.
She has already done mental math from the per-night rate and concluded it is insufficient. The current information order forced her to calculate instead of presenting the answer.

evidence.quote: A high anchor selectively primed the names of luxury brands (Mercedes, Audi), whereas the low anchor primed brands associated with mass-market cars (Volkswagen).
evidence.insight: Leading with a monthly total of $4,800+ primes 'serious income' associations. Leading with $85/night primes 'small side income' associations. The information order determines the associative network activated.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Monthly aggregate income is primary because it is the host's decision criterion. Per-night rate is quarternary because it is the platform's unit of sale, not the host's unit of evaluation. The hierarchy must serve the host's decision tree, not the platform's data model.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Progressive disclosure from monthly total → comparison against host's minimum → per-tenant breakdown → per-night detail. Each level is available on demand but only the first level is shown by default.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Primary display: 1 number (monthly estimate), 1 comparison (vs. host minimum). Maximum 2 data points visible before interaction. No mental math required from the host at any level.
scan_order: Comparison to host's monthly minimum or market rate
Number of tenants contributing to total
exclude: Per-night rate as a primary display element
Occupancy assumptions and calculations
Platform fee structure (show net income, not gross minus fees)
Seasonal adjustment details (handle automatically, show net result)

elements.title: Guest Trust Profile: Employment-Purpose-Origin Information Order
elements.problem: Tammy evaluates guests in a specific order: (1) employment/employer, (2) purpose of stay, (3) origin location (non-local preferred), (4) payment ability. The current proposal view likely leads with booking details (dates, duration, pricing) — which is the platform's transactional data, not the host's trust-evaluation data. When the host opens a proposal and sees dates and prices first, their System 1 has no trust data to work with, so it fills the gap using the availability heuristic: the most vivid guest memories available are negative (fraudulent credit cards at 13:31, local renters causing problems). Without a trust-positive anchor at the top of the information hierarchy, every proposal triggers the host's worst-case availability bias.
elements.solution: Design a Guest Trust Profile that appears at the top of every proposal, structured in the host's evaluation order: (1) EMPLOYER & ROLE: Company name, job title, employment verification status. This is the strongest trust anchor. (2) PURPOSE OF STAY: Why they are in the city, duration of work assignment, and project type. This provides context that makes the guest's presence legible and predictable. (3) ORIGIN: Home city and state. Non-local origin is a positive signal for Tammy ('they're not going to stay there permanently'). (4) PAYMENT STATUS: Pre-authorization status, deposit readiness, payment method. This confirms ability to pay without requiring the host to investigate. Only after this trust profile does the proposal show booking details (dates, duration, pricing). The trust profile acts as a priming anchor that activates 'reliable professional' associations before the host encounters any transactional data.

evidence.quote: If they're a nurse and they're going to be working at a particular hospital, I know where they're working, I know what they're doing.
evidence.insight: Employment data is her primary evaluation criterion. It must be the first thing she sees, not something she has to seek out.

evidence.quote: Local people... check from their employer... What are they there for?
evidence.insight: Her vetting questions form a specific sequence. The information architecture must mirror this sequence to match her cognitive flow.

evidence.quote: Personal experiences, pictures, and vivid examples are more available than incidents that happened to others, or mere words, or statistics.
evidence.insight: Concrete guest details (employer name, job title, home city) are more effective at countering negative availability bias than abstract trust signals (verification badges, ratings). Specificity defeats availability.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Trust-evaluation data precedes transactional data. The host must form a positive impression of the guest before encountering booking details, because the trust impression determines whether booking details are even evaluated.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Guest Trust Profile is fully visible by default at the top of every proposal. Booking details (dates, pricing, duration) appear below the trust profile. Detailed guest history (past stays, reviews) is available on expansion.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Trust Profile: 4 data points maximum (employer, purpose, origin, payment status). Each data point should be a single line of text. The entire profile should be scannable in under 5 seconds.
scan_order: Booking dates and pricing (below the fold)
exclude: Generic trust badges without specific data
Guest's platform join date (irrelevant to Tammy's criteria)
Guest rating average (too abstract; she wants specifics)
Social media links (privacy concern, not relevant to her vetting)

elements.title: Anti-Airbnb Differentiation Signals in First-Scan Position
elements.problem: Tammy's Airbnb availability cascade means that any platform which looks, sounds, or feels like Airbnb is immediately categorized in the 'bad platform' associative network. Kahneman's research on priming shows that System 1 categorization happens before conscious evaluation. If Split Lease's first-scan information (the content visible without scrolling or clicking) does not explicitly signal differentiation from Airbnb, the host's System 1 categorizes it as 'another Airbnb' and subsequent information is processed through the negative filter. The current first-scan information likely includes standard platform elements (search, listings, ratings) that are visually and structurally similar to Airbnb, triggering the category association.
elements.solution: Place explicit differentiation signals in the first-scan position (visible without scrolling on first visit). Three critical signals based on Tammy's specific Airbnb grievances: (1) HOST POLICY CONTROL: 'You set your policies. We enforce them.' This directly counters Airbnb's policy-override behavior, which is Tammy's primary complaint. (2) GUARANTEED INCOME: 'Your minimum monthly income, guaranteed by paired tenants.' This addresses the income uncertainty that makes Airbnb feel unreliable. (3) NO UNILATERAL CANCELLATION: 'Your bookings are protected. We don't cancel on behalf of guests.' This counters the pandemic cancellation betrayal. These signals must be in the first-scan position — the area visible within 2 seconds of page load, before any scrolling. They serve as category-breaking anchors that prevent the Airbnb association from forming.

evidence.quote: I really can't stand Airbnb... that is the model of bad customer service... They take too much control over damages.
evidence.insight: Tammy's Airbnb grievances are specific and actionable: policy overrides, damage control seizure, guest-favorable cancellations. Each grievance is a differentiation opportunity.

evidence.quote: VRBO... they kind of let you set the policy. They kind of just take a more hands off approach.
evidence.insight: VRBO's hands-off positioning is the positive anchor. Split Lease's first-scan messaging should echo VRBO's host-control model.

evidence.quote: System 1 tries its best to construct a world in which the anchor is the true number.
evidence.insight: If the first information the host encounters is 'You control your policies,' System 1 constructs a 'host-controlled platform' world. If the first information is a listing grid that looks like Airbnb, System 1 constructs an 'Airbnb clone' world. First-scan position determines the world System 1 builds.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Differentiation signals are primary, above marketplace content. The host must know what kind of platform this is before seeing any listings, pricing, or features. Category identification precedes feature evaluation.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Differentiation signals are always visible in first-scan position. Marketplace content (listings, search) appears below. Feature details are available on scroll or click. The hierarchy is: what we ARE → what we DO → how we DO it.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: 3 differentiation signals maximum in first-scan. Each signal: 1 headline (under 8 words) + 1 supporting sentence (under 15 words). Total first-scan text: under 70 words.
scan_order: Call-to-action (explore listings or set up your portfolio)
exclude: Generic marketplace hero images
Guest-facing content (search bars, 'where do you want to stay')
Platform statistics (X listings, Y hosts) that carry no differentiation value
Testimonials from hosts who do not match the professional multi-property profile

elements.title: Portfolio Dashboard: Multi-Unit Income Overview
elements.problem: Tammy manages 13-14 units. She thinks in portfolios: total monthly income across all properties, occupancy across all units, seasonal performance trends. The current dashboard likely shows individual listings, forcing her to mentally aggregate across pages to understand her portfolio performance. This forces unnecessary cognitive load and prevents the formation of a positive 'portfolio income' anchor. Kahneman's availability heuristic predicts that the most recently viewed listing (which might be underperforming) will disproportionately influence her assessment of the entire platform. Without a portfolio-level view, each individual listing's performance is evaluated in isolation, and one underperforming unit makes all of Split Lease feel unsuccessful.
elements.solution: Design a portfolio-level dashboard as the primary landing view for multi-property hosts. Information hierarchy: (1) PRIMARY: Total monthly income across all units — one large number that serves as the positive anchor. (2) SECONDARY: Income per unit as a compact list or grid, each showing monthly total and occupancy percentage. (3) TERTIARY: Comparison against the host's stated monthly minimums (green if meeting anchor, amber if close, red if below). (4) QUARTERNARY: Detailed per-unit booking history, available on drill-down. The portfolio dashboard ensures that every visit to the platform begins with the aggregate number, not with individual listings. This creates a positive anchoring effect: even if one unit underperforms, the aggregate income may still meet the host's total portfolio target.

evidence.quote: I have like 13, 14 [units]... I have nine units in New York. I have two brownstones and then I have units that I rent in the bay area.
evidence.insight: She describes her portfolio in aggregate (total units, geographic distribution), not as individual properties. The dashboard must match this mental model.

evidence.quote: I can look to people all day long at 5,000 a month for the two bedroom, one bath.
evidence.insight: Her income anchor is per-unit but her operational model is portfolio-wide. The dashboard must show both: per-unit against its minimum AND total portfolio income.

evidence.quote: A salient event that attracts your attention will be easily retrieved from memory... You are therefore likely to exaggerate the frequency.
evidence.insight: Without a portfolio view, the last listing checked becomes disproportionately salient. A portfolio aggregate view prevents one underperforming unit from anchoring the host's assessment of the entire platform.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Portfolio aggregate is primary; individual unit performance is secondary. The host's first data point must be the total portfolio number, which anchors positively before any individual unit detail is explored.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Dashboard loads with portfolio aggregate → scroll/expand for per-unit breakdown → click into individual unit for booking details. The host must see the big number before the small numbers.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Portfolio summary: 1 primary number (total income) + N unit cards (1 line each: unit name, monthly income, occupancy %). No more than 9 units visible without scrolling on desktop.
exclude: Individual listing edit buttons in the portfolio summary view (separate concern)
Guest details at portfolio level (belongs in per-unit drill-down)
Calendar views at portfolio level (too much visual data)
Promotional or platform update banners (compete with income data for attention)

elements.title: Risk-Reduction Evidence Ladder for Platform Trust
elements.problem: Tammy has developed a comprehensive risk-reduction system: Zelle (no chargebacks), electronic locks (access control), upfront payment (financial commitment), employer verification (identity validation), onsite managers (rapid response). Each of these represents a concrete risk mitigation she can see and control. The platform must communicate its own risk-reduction measures with equivalent specificity and concreteness, or the host perceives the platform as less safe than her existing system. Kahneman's research shows that abstract reassurances ('your property is protected') are processed differently from concrete mechanisms ('if the guest does not pay, we debit their pre-authorized deposit within 24 hours'). Availability bias means concrete mechanisms are more memorable and emotionally reassuring than abstract promises.
elements.solution: Present platform risk-reduction measures as a concrete evidence ladder, each rung matching one of the host's existing risk-mitigation tools: (1) PAYMENT SECURITY: 'Payments are collected upfront before the guest arrives. Funds are held in escrow and released to you on [schedule].' This mirrors her Zelle upfront-payment model. (2) GUEST VERIFICATION: 'Every guest provides employer verification, government ID, and purpose of stay before their proposal reaches you.' This mirrors her vetting checklist. (3) ACCESS CONTROL: 'Electronic lock codes are generated per stay and expire automatically.' This mirrors her electronic lock system. (4) DISPUTE RESOLUTION: 'You set your policies. If a guest violates them, we enforce your terms — not ours.' This counters the Airbnb policy-override fear. Each rung provides a concrete mechanism, not an abstract promise. The ladder is disclosed progressively during the evaluation-to-onboarding transition.

evidence.quote: People are paying upfront. If they give you their money upfront, you know they have a place to stay... I also have electronic locks.
evidence.insight: Her risk mitigation is concrete and mechanism-based. Platform trust communication must match this specificity level.

evidence.quote: I've been using Zelle... there's really no room for error with them.
evidence.insight: Zelle represents zero-chargeback certainty. The platform's payment mechanism must communicate equivalent certainty, not just 'secure payments.'

evidence.quote: Personal experiences, pictures, and vivid examples are more available than incidents that happened to others, or mere words, or statistics.
evidence.insight: Concrete risk-reduction mechanisms are more available in memory than abstract promises. 'Pre-authorized deposit debited within 24 hours' is more powerful than 'your payment is protected' because it creates a vivid, specific image.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Each risk-reduction rung must be concrete (mechanism) before abstract (promise). The mechanism is primary; the promise is the wrapper. Show HOW it works, then state WHAT it guarantees.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The most relevant risk-reduction mechanism appears at each decision point: payment security at pricing, guest verification at proposal review, access control during active lease onboarding, dispute resolution at policy setup. Full ladder available on a dedicated 'How We Protect You' section.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Each risk-reduction rung: 1 mechanism sentence + 1 outcome sentence. Maximum 20 words per rung. Full ladder: 4 rungs maximum visible at once.
scan_order: Most relevant risk mechanism for current phase
Comparison to the host's existing tool (if applicable)
exclude: Legal disclaimers at the point of trust-building (move to terms page)
Insurance details (too complex for trust-building; keep in detailed docs)
Competitor comparisons by name (avoid activating negative associations)
Statistics about platform safety ('99.9% of stays are problem-free') — too abstract for availability-bias-driven trust
